title: Business Insider Parent Nears Deal to Buy Controlling Stake in Morning Brew
summary: The startup, Morning Brew, has a popular email newsletter on business and finance. Business Insider parent Insider Inc. is nearing a deal to acquire a controlling stake in Morning Brew, a news startup known for a popular email newsletter on business and finance, according to people familiar with the situation.

title: Supreme Court Allows Trump Administration to End Census Count Early
summary: Civil-rights groups, cities said ending count early would lead to undercount of some Americans. The Supreme Court on Tuesday approved Trump administration plans to end the 2020 census before a Oct. 31 deadline, suspending lower court orders requiring the decennial count to continue according to a schedule announced in April.

title: Amy Coney Barrett Faces Lawmakers' Questions
summary: Supreme Court nominee sidesteps questions about abortion, says she isn't hostile to the Affordable Care Act and gun control. WASHINGTON-Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett told senators Tuesday she wouldn't impose her personal views on the law, as she sidestepped questions about abortion rights and said she isn't hostile to the Affordable Care Act and gun control.

title: Alternative Meat Producer Raises Additional $135 Million to Drive Growth
summary: The Livekindly Collective, led by a former Unilever executive, raised its capital from Blue Horizon Corp, Trustbridge Partners and EQT, among others. A new alternative meats business led by a longtime Unilever PLC executive has raised $335 million since March to compete in an increasingly crowded market.

summary: Frank Conforti will take on the role of co-president and chief operating officer. Urban Outfitters Inc. promoted its finance chief to chief operating officer, a move that comes as the number of COOs at large U.S. companies is declining.

title: Study of Eli Lilly Covid-19 Drug Paused Due to Safety Concern
summary: Drugmaker halted trial testing that explored use of its antibody drug in combination with remdesivir. A federally funded clinical trial testing an experimental Eli Lilly & Co. Covid-19 treatment has been paused due to a potential safety concern, the company said.

summary: Lingering pandemic shutdowns in key locations including New York are discouraging studios from releasing movies, says CEO Adam Aron. AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. title: Theater Chain AMC Says It Could Run Out of Cash by Year-End
summary: Attendance is down about 85% on a same-theater basis from last year since reopening began, company says. The world's largest movie-theater company may run out of cash by year's end if it doesn't raise additional funds or get more people back to theaters following pandemic shutdowns that have disrupted businesses dependent on consumers gathering in public spaces.

title: Is There Still Hope for the Trump Campaign?

The best responses will be published that night.

title: Exiled Chinese Businessman's Manhattan Apartment Is Put in Bankruptcy
summary: Guo Wengui's residence in Sherry-Netherland Hotel is placed in chapter 11 amid legal dispute. A palatial Manhattan residence occupied for years by exiled Chinese businessman Guo Wengui has been put under bankruptcy protection amid a legal dispute over the multimillion-dollar apartment on the 18th floor of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.

title: Virginia's Voter-Registration Site Goes Offline on Last Day to Register
summary: State officials say work for a roadside utilities project struck a Verizon fiber-optic cable. Virginia's voter-registration website went offline for much of Tuesday on the state's last day to register before the Nov. 3 election, in what officials attributed to an accidental cutting of a fiber-optic cable.

title: J&J Vaccine Pause Shows Challenges Still Ahead for Covid-19 Shots
summary: Halt of trials for two of four of the West's most advanced vaccines tempers global hopes. The pause of Johnson & Johnson 's Covid-19 vaccine trials poses another setback for global efforts to develop a shot to protect lives and jump-start economies battered by the pandemic, as well as a reminder of the challenges of fast-tracking vaccine development.

title: Who's Afraid of Amy Coney Barrett?
summary: Democrats are treating the nominee like a prop at a campaign rally.. The Senate confirmation hearings for Amy Coney Barrett may lack for political drama, but they are still instructive. They are revealing the deep fault lines over the Supreme Court, and how Democrats view it as a mini-legislature to achieve policy goals, rather than a real judicial body.

title: Lakers Fans, Global Bureaucrats Oppose Lockdowns
summary: As world-wide cases surge but fatalities don't, resistance grows to Covid mandates.. On Sunday night thousands gathered in Los Angeles neither to pray nor to protest, but simply to salute their favorite basketball team and enjoy the camaraderie of fellow fans.

title: Sheldon Whitehouse Does Glenn Beck
summary: At Amy Coney Barrett's confirmation hearing, the Rhode Island Democrat offers his theory of everything.. Viewers of cable TV might recall when Glenn Beck would get out the chalkboard after the financial panic and lay out in astonishing detail the multiple and supposedly nefarious connections among Goldman Sachs , Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner and various others in the vast Wall Street conspiracy. Mr. Beck has retreated to the internet as far as we know, but American politics has found his spiritual doppelganger in Sheldon Whitehouse.

title: Mail Voting Done Better
summary: If you're not registered in Oregon, it's too late. See you in 2024.. Doubts about America's foray into mass mail voting have been pooh-poohed for months. Western states have pulled off all-absentee balloting for years, the news write-ups say in a throwaway line. What do they have that the rest of us lack? Well, for one thing, check out their solid deadlines.

summary: U.S. investor's move sounds a note of confidence in troubled European banking sector. U.S. investor Capital Group Cos. has raised its stake in Deutsche Bank AG , sounding a rare note of confidence in prospects for the troubled European banking sector.

summary: The Staggers Rail Act of 1980 got American freight transportation back on track.. The term "deregulation" has become polarized in Washington. But there was a time when both parties could agree on the benefit of targeted regulatory reform.

title: The Korean War's Lesson for Taiwan
summary: Stalin nixed Kim Il-Sung's plan to invade the South until he was convinced the U.S. wouldn't strike back.. Beijing has been making a show of hostility toward Taiwan. Last week China released footage of "real combat" it conducted last month in Taiwanese airspace. A Chinese invasion would present the greatest threat to global peace in a generation. The U.S. would confront an agonizing dilemma: risk an armed clash between two nuclear superpowers or abandon a free people to communist tyranny. But there's an alternative-deter the threat by committing to oppose it, by force if necessary.

title: These Are the World's 10 Most Sustainably Managed Companies
summary: The global rankings take into account a range of sustainability metrics. The Wall Street Journal's environment, social and governance research analysts assessed more than 5,500 publicly traded businesses to produce its rankings of the most sustainably managed companies in the world. They looked at sustainability metrics including environment, human capital (internal employee and workplace issues), social capital (external social and product issues), and business model and innovation. Scores reflect the amount of publicly available information about each company's policies, initiatives and performance metrics-all of which can be important indicators of a company's long-term financial performance and the effects it could have on the planet and people. Here are the top 10.

title: An October Day at Walter Reed Hospital
summary: The crowd gathered to pay tribute to Eisenhower on his 78th birthday-which turned out to be his last.. It's an October afternoon on the grounds of the nation's most renowned military hospital. A bitter presidential campaign is in its stretch run. In his room at Walter Reed, a grievously ill man much more accustomed to life in the Oval Office looks out the window, to be greeted by a surprise.

summary: Shelby Steele's new film takes a critical look at the prevailing narrative. It's now under 'content review.'. The incident, and the nationwide coverage it attracted, marked the beginning of a period of mass protests against police, which culminated (let's hope) after the tragic death of George Floyd in Minneapolis this May.

summary: It isn't easy to find companies that are as progressive-or as transparent-as many investors would like. It isn't easy being an environmentally guided investor.

title: Under 45? You're More Likely to Get Covid-19
summary: People aged under 45 account for the majority of cases in many countries. The majority of known Covid-19 infections are among younger people and mortality among 25 to 44 year olds is higher than in previous years, experts say. But people aged 44 and under are still the least likely to die from the virus, data shows. Here are some of the reasons why.

title: Treasury Unit Warns Banks of Unemployment Fraud
summary: As U.S. jobless claims swell during the pandemic, authorities are urging financial institutions to watch for schemes involving unemployment insurance payments. title: New York City Police Seek Input on Reforms After Summer Protests
summary: Department plans to use feedback from public forums to help 'reimagine' policing. The New York Police Department will hold a series of town halls with residents to gather public input on new efforts to make changes to the department's policing, officials said Tuesday.

title: Trump's Drug-Discount Cards Expected to Reach Medicare Recipients After Election
summary: Democrats say plan raises legal questions about misuse of taxpayer dollars. President Trump's plan to send 33 million Medicare beneficiaries a card that can be used to help pay for as much as $200 in prescription drug costs won't be completed until after the election, according to a person familiar with the plan.

title: Apple Reveals Four iPhone 12 Models With 5G Capability
summary: Investors bet a faster connection speed will spur new demand for the smartphone, including by attracting customers who have held off upgrading. Apple Inc. unveiled four iPhone 12 models capable of connecting to a much faster 5G cellular network, bringing new attention to the wireless technology that investors are betting will lead millions of customers to upgrade their devices.

title: Changing Meaning of Tolerance, and Its Lack
summary: I couldn't agree more with Mr. Epstein's condemnation of how the so-called "woke" insidiously torque the concept of tolerance.. Joseph Epstein points to the opinion that "racism isn't systemic, but the absence of fathers in African-American families is," as one of those views that "the tolerant absolutely won't tolerate" ("The Tyranny of the 'Tolerant,'" op-ed, Oct. 10). So true, but aren't conservatives similarly at fault when it comes to the same view? They almost reflexively blame teachers and teachers unions for bad African-American educational outcomes, while confidently offering up vouchers, tax credits and other government solutions as fixes. But isn't the real problem once again one defined by an absence of fathers? More than conservatives want to admit, they too aren't very tolerant of views that don't square with their deeply held view that the poorly educated are victims of teachers as opposed to victims of mistakes made within their own families.

title: What Is the Minimum Wage Really About?
summary: The cost of living varies enormously across the country.. Rep. Donald Norcross ("Biden's Good Case for a $15 Minimum Wage," Letters, Oct. 12) bases his argument for an increase in the minimum wage, in part, on the cost of apartment rent in New Jersey. He has no one to blame but himself. Rents are driven by high taxes (sales, income, real estate, energy, employment, etc.) and restrictions on building new housing imposed by politicians like himself. Cut the taxes and red tape and rents will follow.

title: Requirements for H-1B Visa Shouldn't Be Overly Narrow
summary: The concept that an applicant must have a degree in a specific field in which she or he is looking for work is outdated.. With the new H-1B visa requirements linking a degree in a specific field and job description, I doubt whether Sundar Pichai head of Alphabet/Google, whose degrees are in metallurgical engineering and materials science, would have gotten an H-1B to work in the information-technology sector ("U.S. Imposes New Curbs on H-1B Visas," U.S. News, Oct. 7).

title: Racism and Continuing U.S. Racial Disparities
summary: I wonder what reasons the author believes exist for racial disparities in our society other than racial prejudice?. Regarding Jason L. Riley's "Where Have the Honest Liberals Gone?" (Upward Mobility, Oct. 7): I wonder what reasons the author believes exist for racial disparities in our society other than racial prejudice? The "black underclass" and "black elites" both want safe neighborhoods and better schools for themselves, their families, and their communities. To dismiss the critical race discussions as irrelevant or out of touch to black Americans living in these disadvantaged communities is disingenuous at best, and dangerous at worst. The death of George Floyd, the 1619 Project, and other events are awakening in America another way of looking at how we legislate; how the systems that have evolved have worked to the disadvantage of black Americans. It is only through this reckoning and acknowledgment that we can hope to shift how we view tax policy, health policy, banking policy, and so on, to level the playing field for black Americans.

title: Theranos Founder Elizabeth Holmes Loses Bid to Dismiss Criminal Charges
summary: Ruling by federal judge sets stage for March trial. summary: World's gross domestic product forecast to fall by 4.4% this year, not as sharp as the 5.2% drop projected by IMF in June. title: Bugs Bunny Is Still Making Mischief
summary: As durable at 80 as when he made his debut, the cartoon rabbit is still finding ways to torment his tormentors.. There's a telling moment in the 1940 Tex Avery cartoon "A Wild Hare" when Bugs Bunny sneaks up behind Elmer Fudd, covers his adversary's eyes with his hands, and instructs him to "Guess who!" The hunter reels off a list of contemporary leading ladies, including, as expressed in his exaggerated speech impediment, "Cawole Wombard." Yet even though one of the actresses in the list, "Owivia DeHaviwand," lived until July of this year, the joke has largely been lost on younger generations-because most viewers born after 1970 have barely heard of most of the movie stars of Hollywood's golden age.

title: Regeneron's Coronavirus October Surprise
summary: Trump told me in July that he was more hopeful about therapeutics than about a vaccine. He was prescient.. Did President Trump return to work too soon after coming down with Covid-19? The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in August updated its guidelines for health-care workers recovering from the disease. The CDC recommends that for those with mild to moderate illness, returning to work is permissible when "at least 10 days have passed since symptoms first appeared and at least 24 hours have passed since last fever without the use of fever-reducing medications and symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of breath) have improved." The CDC also notes that "a test-based strategy is no longer recommended because, in the majority of cases, it results in excluding from work health care professionals who continue to shed detectable SARS-COV-2 RNA but are no longer infectious."

title: Trump's 'Cross of Gold' Moment
summary: The president may drive voters into the other party, much like Bryan in the 1890s.. As a bitterly divided country moves toward the November election, it is easy to overlook how unusual the past three decades have been. With Democrats averaging 48.3% of the popular vote and Republicans 46.1% in the past eight presidential elections, the largest Republican margin of victory (7.8%) went to George H.W. Bush in 1988; the largest Democratic margin (7.2%) to Barack Obama in 2008. In four of these elections, neither candidate won a majority of the popular vote; in two, the popular and Electoral College votes diverged.

title: Health and Safety Move to the Fore of Workplace Issues
summary: Alstom, Ebara and other firms that scored high in human capital in a WSJ ranking of most sustainable companies earned strong marks for employee health and safety. The "S" in ESG investing has grabbed the spotlight this year as two major social issues, the coronavirus pandemic and unrest over racial justice, have taken hold in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Best Companies at Managing Environmental Risk
summary: Heavy-goods makers lead the way in this category of the WSJ top 100 sustainably managed companies. A cluster of makers of heavy goods, from steel and cement to glass, leads the companies recognized this year for best practices in managing environmental risk, according to a new ranking by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Georgia Voters Set Record on First Day of Early Voting
summary: State officials say voter enthusiasm is driving turnout and creating long lines. ATLANTA-Georgia voters flooded to polling places on the first day of early voting Monday, creating long waits for some as state election officials cited record turnout due to voter enthusiasm.

title: Save Money, Save the Environment and Help Local Restaurants. There's an App for That.
summary: Too Good to Go lets you buy leftover prepared food that would otherwise go in the trash. I ate some odd meals last week: a turkey wrap for breakfast one day, cheddar cheese and chocolate cake for dinner the next. On a few occasions, I didn't exactly know what the heck I was eating. But it was for a good cause. Not only was I saving the planet by reducing food waste-a cause I care about a little-I was eating cheap, a cause I care about a lot.

title: OPEC Says U.S. Oil Production Recovering Faster Than Expected
summary: Production by the cartel was mostly flat in September, with a sharp drop in Emirati production balancing increases in Iraq and Libya. The U.S. energy industry is recovering more quickly than previously expected from the fall in production from the coronavirus pandemic, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said Tuesday.

title: The Forgotten British Race Car With Ferrari Flair
summary: Resume Subscription. Ford Heacock III, 69, a retired owner of an insurance agency living in Lakeland, Fla., on his 1961 Sunbeam Harrington Alpine, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: Photos: A Connection to Racing-and Family-History
summary: Ford Heacock III shows off his 1961 Sunbeam Harrington Alpine. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Want to Go to the World Series? It'll Never Be This Cheap Again
summary: After a season played in empty ballparks because of the coronavirus pandemic, MLB is allowing a limited number of fans into Globe Life Field in Arlington, Texas. Melissa Giorgio grew up in Southern California obsessed with the Los Angeles Dodgers. She describes herself as one of those people for whom "baseball is life," and she's been hanging on every pitch as her beloved Dodgers have advanced to the National League Championship Series.

title: J&J Pauses Covid-19 Vaccine Trials Due to Sick Volunteer
summary: Company says an independent committee is reviewing the subject's illness. Johnson & Johnson said it has paused further dosing in all clinical trials of its experimental Covid-19 vaccine because a study volunteer had an unexplained illness.

title: Apple, Disney, Amazon.com, J&J: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Amazon.com's Prime Day sales event and Apple's new iPhone will vie with Wall Street banks' earnings reports for the spotlight. Here's what we're watching as markets kick into gear Tuesday.U.S. stock futures are edging down after Johnson & Johnson paused its coronavirus vaccine trials, prompting speculation about when immunization shots might become widely available. Read our full market wrap here.

title: Does Gold Protect Your Investment Portfolio? Think Again
summary: After falling alongside stocks amid March's market panic and again last month, the metal might continue to move with shares for some time. There is no asset that prompts more emotional reactions than gold, so I really shouldn't have dismissed its role in a modern investment portfolio with a mere throwaway line in a recent column.

title: Portland Mayoral Race Turns Tight After Protests and Violence
summary: Incumbent Ted Wheeler faces an invigorated fight from left-wing newcomer Sarah Iannarone amid unhappiness over his handling of civil unrest. Six months of summer protests and violence in Portland, Ore., have turned what looked like an easy re-election for its Democratic mayor into a tight race with a challenger from the left who has never held elected office.

title: 86-Year-Old Artist Sam Gilliam Looks Back on a Tumultuous, Legendary Life
summary: Signed by his first New York gallery only last year, the artist talks about his formalist inventions, his favorite possessions and how, coming to the end of the line, he wants to be remembered. The artist Sam Gilliam has a low timbre to his voice that betrays a quiver. He is not doubtful, exactly. He is proper, preferring to be called Mr. Gilliam. He is certain, too, that his art will stand the test of time. But he is aware that a legacy is necessarily tied up with death. "I'm coming to the end, I guess," he says.

title: Fall in Love With These Autumn Styles
summary: Classic separates and glamorous pieces go together like sunny days and canoes, pine needles and fresh-mown grass, cozy sweaters and chilly air. These days, many of us are finding joy in simpler things: tending to backyard gardens, cooking meals at home, enjoying family nights in. WSJ. Magazine's October cover story, shot at a bucolic retreat in Connecticut with model Lili Sumner and her boyfriend, writer and photographer Ahmed Alramly, captures that mood perfectly. Photographed by Christian MacDonald and styled by Tonne Goodman, classic, casual pieces-tank tops, turtleneck sweaters-mixed with stylish coats and evening gowns evoke a pared-down American glamour. For more fall fashion inspiration, this issue has you completely covered. Be sure to give fringe a try, whether it's a skirt to cut loose in or a new take on a statement cape. And don't be afraid to get cozy in swirly patterns and florals. You might even want to embrace the magical power of dressing up in high-voltage colors and unexpected details. And don't forget the perfect pair of rugged fall boots to tie it all together-plus your mask of choice, of course.

title: U.S. Agents Returned Migrants to Honduras in Unauthorized Operation, Senate Report Says
summary: Democrats on the Foreign Relations Committee say that several hundred U.S.-bound migrants were rounded up in Guatemala and returned to Honduras in January by Customs and Border Protection agents. U.S. border agents working in Guatemala detained Honduran migrants intending to make their way to the U.S. border and returned them to Honduras in an unauthorized operation last January, a review by Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee found.

title: MTA Faces Dire Outlook Without Federal Aid, N.Y. Comptroller Warns
summary: The mass-transit system could be forced to slash service, lay off thousands of workers and delay improvements, Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli says. New York's mass-transit system, facing the worst fiscal crisis in its history, could be forced to cut services and borrow billions of dollars if the federal government doesn't approve a Covid-19 bailout package with transit funding, the state's top fiscal watchdog says.

title: Maersk Lifts Guidance, Will Cut 2,000 Jobs in Restructuring
summary: Danish shipping giant will book a $100 million charge related to layoffs, but increased its full-year guidance on booming freight rates. A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S lifted its full-year guidance Tuesday after noting a faster-than-expected rebound in shipping volumes and freight rates, but cautioned that it will take a $100 million restructuring charge in the third quarter to cover the costs of cutting 2,000 jobs.

title: Blackstone-Backed Lender Is Set for IPO
summary: Lender to go public with a $1.9 billion valuation by merging with blank-check firm Replay Acquisition. Consumer-lending platform and Blackstone Group Inc. portfolio company Finance of America Equity Capital LLC is set to go public with a valuation of $1.9 billion through a blank-check merger, this year's hottest way to list shares.

title: Senior Housing CEO's Sudden Departure Ratchets Up Industry Turmoil
summary: Welltower CEO Thomas DeRosa pioneered changes in senior housing through new uses of technology. The head of the country's largest senior housing owner stepped down unexpectedly last week, the latest setback for an industry that has been among the hardest-hit during the pandemic.

title: Vacation Home Demand Soars During the Covid-19 Pandemic
summary: Hilton Head, S.C., and the Poconos are among the popular destinations where Zillow Group reports higher pending sales. Home sales are booming in popular vacation spots, as the pandemic leads more Americans to seek places to work or relax within driving distance of home.

title: New York Blood Center Plans Expansion on Upper East Side
summary: Mayor de Blasio's administration is focusing on life-science industry as cornerstone of city's pandemic recovery. The New York Blood Center is planning a major redevelopment and expansion of its 90-year-old building on the Upper East Side, as city officials say they are eager to build up the life-science industry in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Chinese City to Test Nine Million for Coronavirus After Finding a Dozen Cases
summary: New cluster in tourist hot spot Qingdao causes country's first significant Covid-19 scare in months. The coastal Chinese city of Qingdao will test its more than nine million residents for Covid-19, authorities said, after the discovery of a dozen new cases linked to a local hospital-the country's most significant virus scare in several months.

title: China Quarterly Car Sales Shift Out of Reverse for First Time in Two Years
summary: A broader economic rebound in the country is now beginning to wash over consumers. BEIJING-China's car market recorded its first quarter of year-over-year sales growth in two years as a broad economic recovery bolstered consumer confidence and discounts boosted demand, especially for electric vehicles.

title: Secrets of Jackie Kennedy Onassis's Hairdresser
summary: A new book, "Kenneth: Shear Elegance," honors the man who created the First Lady's bouffant, Marilyn Monroe's swoop and other hairdos.. Jacqueline "Jackie" Kennedy Onassis has been a muse and inspiration to the fashion industry since honing her first lady style in the early '60s. A new book, "Kenneth: Shear Elegance," focuses on the hairdresser who created her signature bouffant and post-White House hairstyles.

title: India Turns to Economic Overhaul as Growth Prospects Slide Amid Coronavirus
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party pushes through changes to farming and labor regulations. NEW DELHI-With India facing an economic crisis brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, Prime Minister Narendra Modi is looking to deregulation as the cure.

title: Madison Avenue Retail Properties Sell for Decade-Low Price
summary: Deal would represent lowest price recorded in the prestigious neighborhood in a decade. Three buildings on Madison Avenue's main retail corridor have sold for about 80% below peak sales prices in 2014, signaling that depressed Manhattan retail real-estate prices continue to tumble.

title: Tencent Powers Up With a Game-Streaming Super Platform
summary: The two largest game-streaming companies in China will merge into a Twitch-like giant under the control of Tencent. Tencent is already very dominant in mobile games, but a game-streaming giant under its control is a nice power-up-and could be a new way for the company to promote its own content.

title: U.S.-Europe Relations Tested as Talks on Taxing Multinationals Fall Short
summary: Governments are trying to agree on new rules for taxing profits of international companies, especially tech giants. World governments have failed to agree to new rules on taxing the profits of multinational companies, a long-running point of tension between the U.S. and Europe over levies paid by the likes of Apple Inc. and Google and one that has raised the threat of trans-Atlantic tariffs.

title: Global Companies Are Caught Between New Taxes and a Trade War
summary: The prospect of a higher corporate tax rate isn't so unappealing when set against the risk of a chaotic trade and tax battle. Taxes aren't quite the certainty they once seemed to Benjamin Franklin.

title: China Exports Supercharged by Medical Equipment and Work-From-Home Gear
summary: Exports top market expectations for sixth straight month, rising 9.9% from a year earlier in September. BEIJING-China's exports and imports both posted strong gains in September, as a recovery in global and domestic demand provided another boost to the world's second-largest economy.

title: Renters Flock to Suburbia, Upending Decadelong Urbanization Trend
summary: New suburban tenants say the shift to a work-at-home model removed a longstanding barrier to living in these neighborhoods. Apartment rents are rising in suburban markets across the U.S. as city dwellers look for bigger spaces in smaller towns.

title: Covid-19 Is Creeping Into Europe's Schools
summary: Schools are reporting thousands of cases in some of the continent's biggest coronavirus hot spots. There's a new front in Europe's fight to contain the coronavirus pandemic: the classroom.

title: Why You Didn't Notice a Japanese Stock Index Beating the Nasdaq This Year
summary: There's a boom in Japan's high-growth small-cap stocks, but few Western investors have heard. If you're not a Japanese investor, you may not have heard of BASE . It's your loss: The small-cap tech stock, a sort of Japanese Shopify , has beaten Tesla 's rally this year by several hundred percentage points.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Coronavirus Pandemic Speeds Shift to Cleaner Energy
summary: Spending on oil and gas has fallen much more than investment in renewables, according to International Energy Agency. The world's transition to cleaner sources of energy is gaining speed as the coronavirus pandemic accelerates a shift in investment away from fossil fuels, according to the International Energy Agency.
